article:
'Transcription' in the linguistic sense is the systematic representation of
language in written form. The source can either be utterances (speech) or
preexisting text in another writing system, although some linguists consider
only the former to be transcription .

Transcription should not be confused with translation, which means representing
the meaning of a source language text in a target language (e.g. translating the
meaning of an English text into Spanish), or with transliteration which means
representing a text from one script in another (e.g. transliterating a Cyrillic
text into the Latin script).

In the academic discipline of linguistics, transcription is an essential part of
the methodologies of (among others) phonetics, conversation analysis,
dialectology and sociolinguistics. It also plays an important role for several
subfields of speech technology. Common examples for transcriptions outside
academia are the proceedings of a court hearing such as a criminal trial (by a
court reporter) or a physician's recorded voice notes (medical transcription).
This article focuses on transcription in linguistics.
